quote: Don't you think you might've    overpacked that bag?
It'll close.
You don't have to take everything    all at once. It's not like you're    moving to Bajor. One G Twelve is    practically right next door.
I know. But I'm not moving to one    G twelve.
I found some great quarters in    section M.
That's all the way on the other    side of the habitat ring.
Dad, don't get all sentimental on    me.
I don't have a son.
Go ahead, make jokes. But one day    you'll be standing where I am, and    believe me, you won't like it any    more than I do.
Maybe, but right now, I'm standing    here. And I can't wait to spend    my first night in my own place.
See. I told you I'd get it.
Okay, let's see if I've got this    straight. I can visit any time I    want, but I have to call first.    You won't be available for    breakfast or lunch, but I can    count on one dinner a week.
Some weeks, maybe even two.
I've raised a generous young man.        You and Nog, moving in together.    I can remember when I didn't even    want you talking to him.
Things change.
They sure do.
Come in.
Oh. It's you.
Who'd you think it was?
Nog.
How could it be Nog? His ship   hasn't even docked yet.
I guess I wasn't thinking.
So what else is new?
Can I help it if I'm excited? My   son is coming home.
Root beer. His favorite. I don't   know how to thank you, brother.
Ten slips of latinum ought to do    it.
You think he'd mind if I had one    for myself?
I'd mind. My own brother drinking    root beer. It's so... Human.
Mmmm... And bubbly.
That's him, that's him.
Rom.
Just kidding.       Come in.
Wrong again.
Constable. Care for a root beer?
No. But you do have something I    want.
Whatever it is, I didn't do it.
Don't tell me. Tell the    Federation Grand Jury on Inferna    Prime.
Federation Grand Jury? Brother,    what have you done now?
I haven't done anything.       What do they want to talk to me    for?
Oh, I think you know.
Odo, I have no idea what this is    about.
Then you'll have eight days to try    to guess. We leave immediately.
We?
I've been waiting ten years for    you to get what you deserve. And    now that the big moment is here,    I wouldn't miss it for anything.
Let's go.
Brother.
What?
I'll say "hi" to Nog for you.
So, how much longer until we reach    Inferna Prime?
Oh, I'd say... one hundred and    ninety-one hours and seventeen    minutes... give or take a day.
In that case, we'd better find    something to keep ourselves    occupied. Care for a game of    fizzbin?
I don't play cards.
I'll teach you. It's a very    simple game.
Let me put it another way... I    don't want to play cards. And    even if I did, I wouldn't want to    play with you.
Afraid you'd lose?

You know, Odo, I used to think all    your problems stemmed from the    fact that you were a changeling,    isolated from your own kind,    forced to live among strangers who    didn't understand you.        You couldn't eat, you couldn't    drink, you couldn't sleep, you    couldn't make love. Was it any    wonder you had such a bad    disposition?

But now... you're not a changeling    anymore. You're one of us. Life    is yours for the taking. All you    have to do is reach out and grab    it. But do you? No. Because    changeling or solid, you're still    a miserable, self-hating    misanthrope. That's who you are    and that's who you'll always be.
I'm still not playing cards with    you.
Fine, we'll just sit here for a    week in silence.
So what are you reading?
Nothing you'd be interested in.
Don't be so sure.
Quark, give that back.
What are you going to do? Arrest    me?

"He walked toward her, the wooden    deck heaving to and fro beneath    his booted feet. Her hands moved    to the broach at her throat. She    unclasped it and the cloak fell    from her shoulders, her wet    skin glistening in the moonlight.    Lightning flashed and heaven's    thunder roared in rhythm with the    beating of their hearts."
All right. Enough.

Odo, I take it all back. You're    obviously a lot more complicated    than I thought.       If you like that kind of thing I    might be willing to sell you my    first edition of "Vulcan Love    Slave."

This is work, not recreation.    (can see Quark doesn't    buy it)   Books like this give me insight   into the criminal mind. It's a   well known fact that a sizable   percentage of homicides are   motivated by romantic obsession.
Well, no one gets killed in    "Vulcan Love Slave," but it's    still a hell of a read.

Give it up, Quark. You can bait    me, annoy me, question my very    existence, but in the end, we both    know I've won. Because when all    is said and done, I'll be heading    back to D.S. Nine and you'll be    spending the rest of your life in    a Federation penal colony.
I'm not there yet.
I'm afraid I can't do that. This    is a high-security investigation    and I'm not allowed to discuss the    specifics with anyone.       Now, if you don't mind... I have    some reading to do.
Cadet Nog reporting for duty, sir.
At ease, cadet. Have a seat.
Yes, sir. Thank you, sir.

You know, I remember when I did my    sophomore year field study.    Starbase One Thirty-seven. I was    a little apprehensive when I got    there. But it turned out to be    one of the best experiences of my    life.
Yes, sir.
The key to field study is simple.    Keep your eyes and ears open,    follow orders and try not to get    in the way.
Yes, sir. Very good, sir. I    won't let you down.
Now, on a personal note... I'd    like to say how glad I am that you    and Jake are going to be roommates.
Yes, sir.
I'm sure the two of you are going    to have a lot of fun together.
Yes, sir. Time permitting, sir.    I mean, if I'm not too busy.    After all, I am here to work.
Don't worry, sir. I'll look after    him for you. Set a good example.    Keep him out of trouble.
You inspire me with confidence,    cadet. Dismissed.
How'd it go?
I inspire him.
Congratulations. Now don't let    him down.
You can count on me, sir.
Lights.
So what do you think?
I think I've died and gone to the    Divine Treasury. After living in    cadet barracks for the past year,    this is going to be paradise.
I know exactly what you mean.    We're on our own, with no one to    tell us what to do.
Before we unpack, we should call    maintenance to clean this place.
They were here yesterday.
If you want something done right,    you have to do it yourself.
I'll do the cleaning on the odd-   numbered days, and you'll do it on    the even ones.
We're going to clean every day?
No. Just the odd and even ones.
I'd better start bringing in my    things. I don't want to be up too    late unpacking.
So what do you feel like doing    tonight? Dom-jot...    Holosuites... ?
I wish I could. But once we eat    and unpack, it'll be time for bed.    Lights out at twenty-two hundred.
I haven't gone to bed that early    since I was twelve.
Go to sleep whenever you want.    But don't forget, we're hitting    the gym at oh-four-thirty.
The gym?
Muscles, Jake.
I've heard of them.
Good. Because by the time I'm   done with you, you're going to   have some of your very own.
You're doing it again.
Doing what?
Smacking your lips.
No I'm not.
There. Don't you hear that?
For the last four days, all I've    heard is you complaining.
This whole runabout is alive with    annoying little noises. Listen.
To what?
That buzzing sound.
I don't hear a thing.
It started over an hour ago.
If you don't like the noises in    here, why don't you go into the    back?
Because it's even colder back    there than it is up here.
Quark, leave the temperature    controls alone.
I will.       As soon as I get it right.
There it is again.
What?
That buzzing noise. Don't you    hear it?
With all this lip-smacking how   could I hear anything?
Where is it coming from?
Inside your head.
Bzzzzzzzzz.
I said be quiet.
It's coming from in here.
It's probably a defective anodyne   circuit.
Defective anodyne circuits make a   kind of... hissing sound.       This is a buzz.       We've got to open up the panel.
If this is some kind of convoluted   plot to escape...
Stop being so suspicious.
That's odd. The buzzing's changed    pitch.
Let's find out.
Don't tell me. Let me guess.
It's a bomb.
Next time I tell you I hear    something, maybe you'll listen.
Let's hope there is a next time.
I'm going to get a transporter    lock on that thing and beam it out    of here.
What if it's set to go off if    someone tries to transport it?
What do you suggest we do? Wait    for it to explode?
I hope this works.
We did it. We're safe.
I wouldn't be so sure about that.
The comm system's down. The   navigational array's failing.   Environmental controls are badly   damaged.       We're losing atmosphere.
Now what?
Now we find someplace to land.
Land? You mean crash.
It's either that or wait for our   lungs to explode in the vacuum of   space.
I'm picking up a Class-L planet on   long range scanners.
Barely habitable.
More habitable than this thing's    going to be in a few minutes.
How close?
Close enough.       I hope.
If we live through this, whoever    planted that bomb is going to    regret it.
Believe me, you don't want to go    anywhere near the Orion Syndicate.
The Orion Syndicate?       Is that who the Grand Jury's    investigating?
I thought you knew.
If I knew you were involved with    the Orion Syndicate, you'd be on    the Defiant right now, surrounded    by half my deputies.
Let me guess. You were pretending    to know more than you did so I'd    think I had nothing to hide and    say something to incriminate    myself.
(his eyes fixed on the     window)   Something like that.
This is all your fault.
You're the one who's a member of    the Orion Syndicate.
I'm not a member. I just know    people who know people who know    some other people. And besides...
Ahhhhhh!
Someone adjust the temperature.   It's freezing in here.
Actually, it's freezing out there.
Out there?       Oh yeah. I remember now. You    were apologizing for almost    getting us both killed.
If that's how you remember it, you    must've hit your head harder than    I thought.
I guess there's nothing we can do    now except send out a distress    signal and wait to be rescued.
Good plan. Except we lost the    comm system in the explosion.
That's not good.
It gets worse. The replicator's    been destroyed and from what I can    tell the local plants are poisonous.
Then I guess we're stuck with field    rations.
That's right.    (distributing the     rations)   One package for you. And one    package for me. The rest were...
I know, I know. Destroyed in the    explosion. So now what?
Now we either freeze to death or    starve to death. Take your pick.
It's about time you woke up. I    thought you were going to sleep    all day.
You should stretch a little before    you start your workout.
I think I'll pass this morning.
You pass every morning.
You can work out for the both of    us.
You don't know what you're    missing. "Healthy body, healthy    mind."
Please. No cliches before    breakfast.
Orange juice. Extra large.        A healthy way to start your day.
A writer and a poet.
What's this?
"Past Prologue."
What's it doing out here?
I found it while I was cleaning    up.       Really Jake, is it that hard to    put things away when you're done    with them?
You read my story?       What did you think?
"Disposal" is spelled with an "i"
That's it? That's all you have to    say?
I didn't really read it for    content. I mostly corrected your    spelling and grammar.
You changed my words?
Just a few. A preposition here,    some punctuation there.
You can't change a writer's words    without his permission. That's    sacrilege.
All right. Next time, I'll let    you make the changes.
There won't be a next time. From    now on, if you see my stories    lying around, don't read them.    Don't even touch them. Just leave    them right where they are.
No problem.       Just put them away when you're not    working on them.
Time to hit the shower. Duty    calls.
Remember, start with the lighter    weights then work your way up.
Quark? What are you doing back    there?
Do you need any help?
You want to help? Here.
I thought you were supposed to be    repairing the subspace    transmitter.
I was.
Then what's it doing out here?
The signal booster's completely    shot.
Which means there's no way we can    transmit a distress signal through    a planetary atmosphere.
I see. So you tore it out of the    wall in frustration.

Actually, I've come up with a way    to save our lives. All we have to    do is haul this transmitter up to    higher ground. More altitude,    less atmosphere. Go high enough,    and we might be able to get a    signal out.
How much higher do we have to go?
Hmmm... carry the seven, take the    square root, times pi... I'd say...
That high.
I'm ready when you are.
(re: the cold weather     gear)   Where'd you find that?
In the back. It's pretty cozy.
Great. Then I won't need this.    (he takes off the     blanket)   I'll go get a suit for myself and    we can be on our way.
Don't bother. This is the only    one that wasn't destroyed in the    explosion.
So we have one survival suit left    and you're going to wear it?
Finders keepers.       Besides carrying that transmitter    up the mountain should keep you    warm.
How can it be so cold when the sun    is shining?
It's not much of a sun. And this    isn't much of a planet. And    you've got a lot of nerve    complaining about being cold when    you're the one wearing the jacket.
You agreed to take turns.
Under duress.
I hate this. If I were still a    changeling, I could've    shapeshifted into a Vorian    Pterodactyl and flown that damn    transmitter to the top of the    mountain hours ago.
You're the one who wanted to be a    solid.
I never wanted to be a solid.

Oh, please. I used to see you    coming into the bar, watching Morn    eat, eyeing my customers gambling    and flirting with the dabo girls,    and wishing you could be one of    them. Not to mention your    "platonic friendship" with a    certain Bajoran major.
If that's the kind of    psychological insight you dispense    with your drinks, it's a wonder    you have any customers.
Deny it all you want. But the    fact is your people gave you what    you wanted. You're one of us now.
And I finally can sit on a chair    and know with absolute certainty    that it isn't you.
Quark?       If you've damaged that    transmitter...
I'm fine, thank you very much.    And so's the transmitter.
Let me help you up.
No thanks. I think I'll just lay    here and freeze to death.
You've made your point. I'll    carry the transmitter for a while.
And I get to wear the jacket.
But I get the trousers.
You did a good job today, Nog.    You've got an excellent grasp of    mechanical engineering.
Ferengis have a natural talent for    figures, sir.
So where are you posted tomorrow?
Cargo Bay Six, sir. Customs    inspection.
That could be... interesting.
(not looking forward to     it)   If you're planning on being a    customs inspector.
Hey, Nog.
Not again.       When I left this morning, this    place was spotless.
That was nine hours ago.
You can't keep our quarters clean    for one day?
A man's got to live. And    sometimes living is messy.
But it doesn't have to stay messy.    I'm going to the Replimat to get    something to eat. When I come    back I expect to see this place    straightened up.
I'm working on a story. I'll do    it in the morning.
This isn't a story. It's    computerized dom-jot.
Sometimes when I get stuck, I play    dom-jot. It clears my mind.
Well while you're at it, how about    clearing a path to the bedroom?
I told you, I'm busy.
Jake, this isn't what we agreed    to.
We didn't "agree" to anything.    You've been shouting orders ever    since you moved in here. I'm not    in Starfleet.
Lucky for you. You wouldn't last    a day at the Academy.
You're right. I'd die of    embarrassment wearing those    pajamas.
I don't have to take that from an    undisciplined jerk like you.
Enjoy your dom-jot.
Where are you going?
Anywhere but here. I'll get my    things in the morning.
I'll pack them for you.
Don't bother. You couldn't fold    a shirt if your life depended on it.
What's that over there?
It's just another stone.

I can't believe it. We've been    walking for two days and we    haven't seen a single beetle.       I could really go for a beetle    right now. Any kind of beetle,    just as long as it had a little    meat on it.
There are no beetles, Quark.
A nice slug would do.
There're no slugs, either. No    slugs, no beetles, no worms, no    snails. There's nothing here but    trees and rocks and we can't eat    any of it.
If I collapse from hunger, you're    going to have to carry me and the    transmitter.
You're not going to collapse.    We're almost to the tree line.    After that, we'll only have a few    hours of climbing left before we    can set up the transmitter.
A few hours? You mean like three?
More like six.
I can do six. Seven might be    pushing it, but six I can do.
Forget about six hours. How about    six days?
Ten thousand, seven hundred, fifty-   one. Ten thousand seven hundred,    fifty-two.
(getting a little sick     of this)   Quark.
Ten thousand, seven hundred --
Quark.
I just want to know how far we're    going. Every step down means one    extra step up.
Then count to yourself. I don't    want to hear it any more.
Fine. But don't talk to me. It's    hard keeping track.
(ignoring Quark's     request)   By the time the grand jury's    through with you, you'll be    counting years instead of steps.
(still counting in his     head)   You know what's going to make all    this worthwhile? The look on your    face when they let me go.
Let you go? I don't think so.

And you call yourself a detective.       The Orion Syndicate tried to kill    me. They never kill their own.    They don't need to. Any one of    them would take their own life    before they'd testify against the    Syndicate.       Don't you get it? I'm not a    suspect. I'm a witness.       Now you made me lose count.
Ten thousand, seven hundred, and    sixty-eight.
Thank you.
So let me get this straight... you    were never a member of the Orion    Syndicate.
I hate to disappoint you.
But you must've tried to join?
I don't want to talk about it.
If I remember correctly, the Orion    Syndicate has a membership fee...    quite a substantial one.
And the Ferengi Commerce Authority    did seize all your assets.

It's even worse than that isn't    it? You never could afford to    join, could you? All those years    of lying and scheming and    cheating, and you were still too    small-time for the Orions.       I guess you're not as successful    a businessman as you think you    are.
Which means you've spent the last    ten years of your life trying to    catch a nobody. Without much    success, I might add. So you tell    me, which one of us is the bigger    failure.
Ten thousand, eight hundred. Ten    thousand, eight hundred and one...
Snail juice. Extra shells. Make    it a double.
May I join you?
Be my guest.
I wanted to ask you... about my    son. You know? Nog?
I think I've met him.
Have you noticed anything...    strange about him lately?
He seems fine to me. He's just    more... dedicated than when he    left.
I've noticed.
A year at the Academy can do that    to people.
You think it's the Academy?
What else could it be?
I was afraid he might be a    changeling. So while he was    asleep, I drew some blood, just to    make sure.
It's been eight hours. So far so    good.
Rom, he's still your son. He's    just taking his duties very    seriously, that's all.
Tell me about it. Nog's moved    back in with me, you know. It's    horrible. He put me on report the    other day. Said my tool kit was    untidy. That's the exact word he    used. "Untidy."
I wouldn't worry about it. It's    just a phase he's going through.
I was hoping living with Jake    would relax him.
I'm afraid Jake's going through a    phase of his own.        I don't know what's so difficult    about putting a dirty plate back    in the replicator.
I don't know what's so difficult    about putting a dirty plate back    in the replicator.
Nog says Jake is a "slovenly,    undisciplined, unfocused... "    (imitating his son, with     disdain)   "Writer."
Not an unfair assessment, I'm    afraid. Sometimes I wish Jake had    a little of Nog's self-discipline.
And I wish Nog had Jake's ability    to enjoy himself.
Those two could learn a lot from    each other.
If we could only get them in the    same room.
Quark, wake up.
Come on, Quark. We've got a    mountain to climb.
Quark.
Quark!
Wake up.
Stop hitting me.
I thought you were dead.
And you saw that as an opportunity   to vent years of hostility towards    me.
Towards me. Towards me. Hostility.
What's wrong?
What?
I said what's the matter.
I'm deaf.    (he clutches his right     ear)   I'm deaf in my right ear. I can't    hear anything out of it.    (testing, covering his     right ear)   Hello, hello, hello.       Hello, hello, hello.
Would you stop doing that?
You don't understand. A one-eared    Ferengi is only half a man.       We've got to get out of here. My    body's shutting down. It's too    cold. There's not enough food.    I'm dying. we both are.
We're not going to die.
Here. You can have the rest of my    rations.
These aren't rations. These are    crumbs. You can't climb a    mountain on crumbs.
Fine. I'll go myself.
You're going to leave me?
What do you want me to do? Stay    here and trade insults until we   starve to death? I'd rather take    my chances on the mountain.
Whose turn is it to carry the    transmitter?
Yours.
Figures.       Figures.       Figures!
I hate this transmitter. I hate    this mountain. And most of all I    hate the Orion Syndicate for    stranding us here.
I think we both know who's really    to blame.
Don't try to blame this on me,    "Constable." It was your job to    get me to Inferna Prime safely.
You never told me the Orion    Syndicate was after you.
You never asked.
If I had, would you have told me    the truth? Or would you have lied    like you lie about everything?
Have I ever told you how much I    hate that smug, superior attitude    of yours?
Have I ever told you how much I    hate your endless whining, your    pathetic greed and your idiotic    little schemes?
Well I hate...
What do you hate?
You.
That's fine with me. Because I    hate you too. You're nothing but    a petty thief.
And you... are an arrogant prude.
Lecher.
Freak.
Fraud.
Fascist.
Failure.
Quark?
What?
Are you all right?
I'm fine.
I'm not.
This should hold together.
Now we just have to get you on it.
Stop looking at the leg. You'll    pass out again.
Not looking at it doesn't help.   I still know it's there.
I should be the one struggling to    stay conscious. I'm the one in    excruciating pain.
Speaking of pain, this is probably    going to hurt.
Quark, there's no way you're going    to be able to drag me up this mountain.
Watch me.
Stop trying to be a hero. You'll    reach the top faster if you leave    me behind.
You don't get it, do you? I'm not    trying to rescue you. I'm taking    you along as emergency rations.    If you die, I'm going to eat you.
You're joking.
Waste not, want not.
Comfortable?
Not really.
Join the club.
Quark...
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: It's over.
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: What do you mean over?
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: I can't move. We'll have to set    up the transmitter here.
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: We're not high enough. You have    to leave me here and go on yourself.
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: Don't you understand? I can't do   it. I'm half frozen and I haven't   eaten for two days. My muscles   won't work anymore.
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: Odo?
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: Well say something.
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: What's there to say? If we stay   here, we're dead.
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: I can't go any farther.
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: If Sisko were here, do you think   he'd give up? Or Worf? Or Dax?
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: They're not here.
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: That's right. It's just us.
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: Give me the transmitter.
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: What for?
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: I said, give it to me.
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: What are you doing?
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: What does it look like?
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: You'll never make it.
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: Maybe not.
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: You're trying to embarrass me,    aren't you? You're trying to    shame me into carrying that thing    the rest of the way on my own.
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: It's not going to work. You might    as well accept the inevitable and    die with dignity. That's what I'm    going to do. I'm just going to    sit here... and die.    (a beat, softly, to    himself)   my brother will get the bar, my   nephew will be completely   corrupted by the Federation and   end up a Starfleet captain, and my   bones will lie here and freeze...   unsold and unmourned.
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: Try not to break your other leg    while I'm gone.
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: I'll do my best.
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: Good luck.
scene: 48   EXT. FARTHER UP THE MOUNTAIN - DAY

quote: Come in.
Dad? I though you were going to    call first.
Jake. We've got a problem.
What's wrong?
According to station regulations,    these quarters require two or more    occupants. I'm afraid you're    going to have to move out.
Smaller quarters. All right, if   I have to.
I'm afraid that's the problem,   Jake. We don't have any smaller   quarters available.
So where do I go?
I guess back home with me.
You're kidding.
Unless we can find you a roommate.
Cadet.
Sir, I really must protest.
Cadets don't have that privilege.
And neither do you. Now I know   that you're two very different   people, but you're still friends.   And somehow, some way, you'll make   this work.
I don't know.
Neither do I.
Well I do.
And I'm your captain...       And your father.       So what I say goes. Good day,   gentlemen.
The place hasn't changed much, has   it?
I guess not. Are you going to   start cleaning again?
No, I've got to study.
Good, because it would take a   while to clean up this... pigsty.
It's not so bad.
It's bad.
Yeah.
You want to go to the gym?
Healthy body, healthy mind.
